grants_details.name: Active Citizen Grant
grants_details.desc: The Active Citizen Grant encourages ground-up initiatives through innovating and organising activities in any of the following three domains: sports volunteerism, physical activity or health & wellness initiatives.
grants_details.guideline_html:
We support community sporting events/projects that fulfil any of the following objectives:
  • Engage the community with meaningful and impactful volunteering opportunities.
  • Demonstrate innovative ways of engaging and inspiring the community through sport, physical activity or health & wellness initiatives.
  • Incorporate elements of “Care” that contribute towards building a caring society e.g. by providing opportunities for social mixing among different groups, offering volunteering platforms for the community to give back to society, rallying participation and contribution behind a good cause.

Who can apply?

Anyone can apply, but Team Nila projects should promote/involve sport volunteerism, while YouthCreates projects should support youth-led sporting initiatives and Team Singapore projects should strengthen affinity for Team Singapore athletes.

More details on eligibility are available in the grant guidelines.

When can I apply?

All year round for Team Nila, Team Singapore & YouthCreates.

How much funding can you receive?

YouthCreates, Team Nila & Team Singapore are capped at $20,000.

grants_details.name: Asia-Ready Exposure Programme (AEP)
grants_details.desc: Supports projects that provide youth with industry and cultural exposure to ASEAN member states, China and India, up to $1,000 per eligible youth.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Asia-Ready Exposure Programme (AEP) supports educational institutions based and registered in Singapore to provide youths with opportunities to gain industry and cultural exposure to ASEAN member states, China and/or India (ACI).

The AEP aims to:

  1. Increase youth awareness and understanding of the social, cultural and political dimensions of the ACI cities;
  2. Increase awareness of the economic growth trajectories and opportunities in the ACI markets; and
  3. Broaden personal growth opportunities and youth ACI networks.
Interested applicants are to read the AEP Factsheet and FAQ, complete the online application and submit the required documents to NYC at least 3 months before the proposed AEP Project Start Date.

Who Can Apply?

Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs, e.g. Institute of Technical Education, Polytechnic, University, Private Education Institution, Madrasah) based and registered in Singapore

When to Apply?

Application is open throughout the year.

Application should be submitted at least 3 months before the proposed AEP Project Start Date.

Applicants who require assistance to fine-tune their proposals are encouraged to send the AEP proposal to AEP_enquiries@nyc.gov.sg before the 3 months submission timeline and factor in adequate time to amend the proposal.

How much funding can you receive?

Up to S$1,000 per eligible youth, subject to a grant cap* per institution per financial year

*confirmed annually on a case-by-case basis

Eligible youths refer to youths who meet all 4 criteria below:

  1. 15 to 35 years old;
  2. Singapore Citizens or Singapore Permanent Residents (PR);
  3. Currently studying in Institutes of Higher Learning (e.g. ITE Colleges, Polytechnics, Universities, Private Education Institutions, Madrasah etc.); and
  4. Have not been funded under the same life stage (i.e. education level) before.

The grant will generally be disbursed in two tranches, depending on the duration of the project and other consideration factors. The remaining grant will be disbursed upon fulfilment of the deliverables and receipt of satisfactory report(s) of the project.

grants_details.name: Charities Capability Fund (CCF)
grants_details.desc: Supports exempt/registered charities and Institutions of a Public Character to enhance governance/management capabilities and operational efficiency.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Charities Capability Fund (CCF) (formerly known as VWOs-Charities Capability Fund (VCF)) aims to enhance the governance and management capabilities of charities and Institutions of a Public Character (IPCs); as well as to enhance the operational efficiency of charities and IPCs to facilitate their submission of returns via the Charity Portal.

The five grants under CCF are:

  1. Training Grant
    2. Provides co-funding for training courses to help charities comply with regulatory requirements and build good governance standards. For CCF Training Grant, your charity may submit its applications online through this link at least 1 month before the commencement of the project.
  2. Consultancy Grant
    3. Provides co-funding for the engagement of external consultants to review and draft policies and standard operating procedures for the charity, and in attaining organisational excellence certifications and accreditations in key governance and management areas.
  3. Info-Communications Technology (ICT) Grant
    4. Provides co-funding for charities to harness ICT to digitise their operations to increase efficiency and to facilitate efforts in being more transparent and accountable to stakeholders and members of the public.
  4. Shared Services Grant
    5. Provides co-funding for charities to outsource their corporate functions such as payroll, finance, accounting, human resource and information technology functions to third-party service providers.
  5. Collaboration Grant
    6. Provides co-funding for ground-up collaborations projects that could enhance charities’ governance, productivity, operational efficiency and capabilities development. This is to incentivise charities to consolidate their needs and build capabilities/solutions that can be co-shared among charities.

grants_details.name: Charities Capability Fund (CCF) - Training Grant
grants_details.desc: The CCF Training Grant supports training courses (local classroom-based courses and local/overseas online courses) for charities' board members and staff (who have served in the charities for at least 6 months with an official designation) in key governance and management areas.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Training courses (local classroom-based courses and local/overseas online courses) for charities' board members and staff (who have served in the charities for at least 6 months with an official designation) in key governance and management areas.

This includes courses on:

  • Board Governance
  • Conflict of Interest
  • Strategic Planning
  • Programme Management
  • Human Resource and Volunteer Management
  • Financial Management, Internal Controls, Risk Management
  • Fundraising Practices
  • Disclosure and Transparency
  • Public Image/Communications
  • Digitalisation/Data Protection/Cyber Security
  • Leadership and Organisational Development
  • Anti-Money Laundering/Countering the Financing of Terrorism
  • Crisis Management, Business Continuity Planning
  • Other training courses that are aimed at improving the governance and management aspects of charities.

Who can Apply?

All exempt, registered charities and IPCs can apply for the CCF Training Grant for its board members, staff and sub-committee members in key governance and management areas. Staff and sub-committee members should have completed at least six months of service with their respective charities.

When to apply?

Charities may submit its applications at least 1 month before the commencement of the course to be considered for funding.

How much funding can you receive?

  • For Singaporeans/Permanent Residents:

    Up to 80% of course fee, capped at $1,000 per course or $500/full-day (8hrs) or $250/half day (4hrs) per participant, whichever is lower.

  • For Employment Pass/Work Permit Holders/S Pass Holders:

    Up to 60% of course fee, capped at $750 per course or $375/full-day (8hrs) or $187.50/half-day (4hrs) per participant, whichever is lower.

grants_details.name: Communities of Care Grant
grants_details.desc: The Communities of Care Grant (COC) provides grant funding/support to individuals and organisations who wish to run a sports programme to benefit underserved and vulnerable populations in Singapore.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Communities of Care Grant (COC) provides grant funding/support to individuals and organisations who wish to run a long-term sports programme (minimally 1 year) for social good. The proposed programme must benefit an underserved and vulnerable population in Singapore (e.g. children and youth from low-income or at-risk backgrounds, isolated seniors, persons with disabilities and special needs).

The COC Starter Grant aims to kick start localised/smaller scale sport-based engagement and/or social development programmes for the underserved and the vulnerable in the community. It may support the inclusion of a sport component in existing non-sport programmes for the vulnerable and the underserved or strengthen the delivery of existing sport programmes for the vulnerable and the underserved.

The COC Development Grant seeks to provide multi-year support to well-run & knowledgeable organisations to engage multiple constituent groups and profiles through sports in various towns/locales, facilitate partnerships in the towns/locales through sport programmes, and catalyse a vibrant ecosystem of sport for social good in the town/locale.

Who can apply?

Starter Grant - Individuals/Groups (e.g. ground up initiatives, members of registered societies), Social service agencies, Non-profit organisations, National sport agencies / National disability sport agencies, Social enterprises.

Development Grant - Established social service agencies, community-based organisations and/or social enterprises.

When can I apply?

The Communities of Care Grant is open for applications throughout the year.

How much funding can you receive?

Starter Grant - Successful applicants can receive up to $50,000 in grant funding.

Development Grant - Successful applicants can receive up to $200,000 in grant funding in the first year, up to $150,000 in the second year, and up to $100,000 in the third year.

grants_details.name: Community Capability Trust (CCT)
grants_details.desc: CCT is dedicated to strengthening Social Service Agencies (SSAs) through sustainable use of resources, to deliver better service outcomes.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Community Capability Trust (CCT) is a Charitable Trust set up to strengthen our social service agencies (SSAs) capabilities and capacities, so that SSAs can deliver better service outcomes to their users.

Transformation Sustainability Scheme (TSS)

Provides funding to support SSA’s capability development in organisational health domains through projects including consultancy and digital solutions.

Organisational Health Diagnostic Scheme (OHDS)

Provides funding for SSAs to do an in-depth analysis of organisational health, and facilitate strategic planning of capability building efforts.

Eligibility

  • Applicant must be a NCSS member or a MSF-funded organisation.
  • The Organisational Health Framework for Social Services (OHFSS) and its assessment tool is a comprehensive framework that empower SSAs to identify their strengths and areas for development. By taking a holistic view of their organisational health, SSAs can strategically plan their capability-building efforts to achieve sustainable outcomes. OHFSS assessment is mandatory for all CCT applications.
  • If your organisation is applying for funding for consultancy, bespoke digital solutions and/or project implementation costs to implement the consultancy or digital projects, please note that your organisation must complete organisational health diagnostics before applying.

grants_details.name: Community Care Manpower Development Award (CCMDA)
grants_details.desc: CCMDA caters for entry and advanced skills training in a range of clinical and non-clinical areas for both in-service and fresh entrants. Its Visiting Expert scheme also funds the invitation of a local or overseas expert to visit your organisation for training.
grants_details.guideline_html:
CCMDA aims to support the attraction, development and retention of manpower in the Community Care sector. It covers short courses, formal academic programmes and attachments to local or overseas healthcare and Community Care facilities.

It also provides training support to General Practitioners (GPs) with a passion and desire to serve the needs of our seniors by providing medical services to clients/residents of Community Care organizations.

Its Visiting Expert scheme provides funding support for Community Care organisations to invite local and/or overseas experts with specialised areas relevant to the Community Care sector to impart their skills and share their knowledge with the local Community Care audience.

Click here for more information on CCMDA.

Who Can Apply?

CCMDA is open to all Community Care organisations providing elder care services. The organisations can apply for in-service staff and fresh entrants.

When to Apply?

Applications are accepted throughout the year.

How much funding can you receive?

CCMDA will fund up to 90% of the course fees and other relevant expenditure. The remaining 10% will be co-funded by the sponsoring/hiring organisation.

For the Visiting Expert scheme, CCMDA will fund up to 90% of fundable expenses, with the organisation co-funding the remaining expenses.

grants_details.name: Community Care Nursing Leadership Programme (CCNLP)
grants_details.desc: The Community Care Nursing Leadership Programme (CCNLP) aims to ensure the continuity of nursing leadership and facilitate the succession planning of nursing leaders in the Community Care sector.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Community Care Nursing Leadership Programme (CCNLP) is a talent development programme which aims to build nursing leadership bench-strength for the Community Care sector, offering a structured pathway for senior nurses to grow into leadership roles. Depending on their stage of career, these senior nurses can be placed on two different tracks in building their competencies:

  1. Three-Year Track for Nurse Managers (NMs) or equivalent who are able to assume leadership roles sooner and address more immediate gaps in succession planning; and
  2. Five-Year Track for Senior Staff Nurses (SSNs) or equivalent with a longer career and leadership runway.

To facilitate the nursing talents’ career development, senior nurses placed on the CCNLP can look forward to various clinical training programmes, leadership development programmes and attachments. In addition, there will be executive coaching, networking and peer learning sessions to enhance support for these senior nurses to transit into new leadership roles.

The Ministry of Health (MOH) and AIC will also work with participating Community Care Organisations (CCOs) to develop an Individual Development Plan (IDP) to track the development and progression of these nursing talent, in accordance to the Community Nursing Competency Framework (CNCF).

Who Can Apply?

Community Care Organisations can apply for their nominated local Registered Nurses (Nurse Managers or Senior Staff Nurses) who completed at least one year of continuous service with them and meet the eligibility criteria below:

  1. Be a Singapore Citizen or Singapore Permanent Resident;
  2. Be a Registered Nurse (RN) with at least five years of nursing experience working in public healthcare institutions, private hospitals or Community Care sector;
  3. Possess strong clinical skills and nursing experience;
  4. Prior experience in the Community Care sector or demonstrated interest to serve in the community; and
  5. Demonstrate potential to become a nursing leader in the Community Care sector.

Eligible individuals local RNs can self-apply by submitting CCNLP application to ccnlp@aic.sg for AIC’s review first. AIC will then work with applicant on their application process.

When to Apply?

CCNLP applications are open throughout FY, i.e. FY20-FY26.

How much funding can you receive?

CCOs will be funded expenses relating to clinical training and local/ overseas attachments for each nursing talent’s developmental track under the programme.

CCNLP Funding GrantThree-Year TrackFive-Year Track
Clinical Training per Nursing Talent$12,000$20,000
Attachments per Nursing Talent$22,000$22,000
Funding Grant per Nursing Talent$34,000$42,000

grants_details.name: Community Integration Fund
grants_details.desc: The CIF supports ground-up projects which create more opportunities for locals and foreigners to interact, and to help newcomers adapt to Singapore society.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Community Integration Fund (CIF) was launched by the National Integration Council (NIC) in September 2009 to support organisations in implementing ground-up initiatives which promote local-foreign integration.
Projects should satisfy at least one of the following objectives to be considered for CIF funding:

  • Provide information and resources on Singapore
  • Encourage social interaction between locals, immigrants and foreigners
  • Encourage emotional attachment to and involvement in Singapore
  • Promote a positive mindset towards integration

Who can apply?

Singapore-registered organisations, including companies and trade unions may apply for CIF.
Individuals should apply through a registered organisation if they wish to apply for the CIF.

More details on eligibility are available in the grant guidelines.

When can I apply?

The CIF is open for applications throughout the year. Applications should be submitted at least 8 weeks before the project start date.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicants can receive up to 80% of supported project expenditure, capped at $100,000, on a reimbursement basis.

grants_details.name: Employment Facilitation – Manpower Recruitment and Training Initiatives (FY22-FY26)
grants_details.desc: The Employment Facilitation - Manpower Recruitment and Training Initiatives (EF-MRTI) is introduced to attract, train, and retain local support care staff in the Community Care sector and to recognise Community Care Organisations (CCOs) for their efforts and investment in the attraction and retention of locals.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Community Care Organisations (CCOs) onboard EF-MRTI and the eligible local support care staff will be eligible for funding support under the Community Care Traineeship Programme (CCTP), Retention Bonus (RB) and On-the-Job Training (OJT) Support.

The funding quantum will be provided in the Letter of Award awarded to CCOs.

Who Can Apply?

Community Care Organisations that meet the following criteria may be eligible for support under the employment facilitation initiatives:

  1. Institutions providing community care healthcare and/or social services that are in line with MOH’s licensing or service requirements; or
  2. Receive subvention funding and/or portable subsidies from MOH for the provision of community care healthcare and social services.

When to Apply?

CCOs may submit their application all year round.

How much funding can you receive?

Information on funding quantum will be communicated by AIC to the organisation after the application is approved.

The funding guidelines will also be provided to the organisation during the grant award stage.

grants_details.name: Enterprise Innovation and Capability Development Grant (InnoGrant)
grants_details.desc: InnoGrant seeks innovative technological solutions to revolutionise sport and fitness experiences.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Sport Singapore's enhanced Enterprise Innovation and Capability Development Grant (InnoGrant) is designed to catalyse the development of stronger growth engines within Singapore's sport and fitness industry. The grant offers financial support of up to S$1,000,000 per project.

The objectives of the InnoGrant are to:

  • Build capability and/or capacity of enterprise in the development and application of technology and/or innovation solutions to the sport and fitness industry;
  • Enable sport and fitness as a platform to encourage and stimulate collaborative research and development with adjacent industries; and
  • Surface innovative ideas/solutions that have the potential to be new growth engine(s) for sport and fitness industry

Please refer to Sport Singapore’s website for more information.

Who can apply?

Sport & fitness organisations in the following categories:
  • Academies & Clubs (A&Cs)
  • Event Organisers & Event Management Companies (EOs/EMCs)
  • Equipment & Apparel
  • Fitness & Wellness Facilities
  • Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs)
  • Media & Broadcasting
  • National Sports Association (NSAs)
  • Sport Facilities

Or Enterprises in adjacent industries pursuing technology solutions that are sport-related or have applicability to sport.

When can I apply?

Grant is open for application throughout the year.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicants can receive up to $1,000,000.

grants_details.name: HARMONY FUND (HF)
grants_details.desc: The Harmony Fund supports creative projects that promote racial and religious harmony in Singapore.
grants_details.guideline_html:
In April 2013, MCCY launched the Harmony Fund to support ground-up initiatives that promote racial and religious harmony. The fund aims to facilitate people-sector initiatives that can complement Government efforts to nurture stronger bonds and build bridges between the different racial and religious communities. Over time, the Fund seeks to cultivate a mature citizenry that takes greater ownership in building a more cohesive Singapore.

Who can apply?

The grant is open to the following:
  • Singaporean/PR individuals
  • Non-profit organisations, and
  • For-profit organisations registered in Singapore undertaking non-profit projects

Please note that community centres and community development councils (CDCs) are not eligible for the grant.
More details on eligibility are available in the grant guidelines.

When can I apply?

The Harmony Fund is open for applications throughout the year. Applications should be submitted at least 8 weeks before the project start date.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicant receives up to 80% of supporting project expenditure, capped at $100,000, on a reimbursement basis.

grants_details.name: Lively Places Fund
grants_details.desc: Interested to start a project to enliven Singapore's public space? Find out if you are eligible to apply for the Lively Places Fund.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Lively Places Fund (LPF) aims to support community-led efforts in enlivening Singapore's public spaces. Under this programme, you can organise activities in public spaces and streets that bring communities together, or create installations that enliven our public spaces. LPF comprises the Project Fund, Building Fund, and MSCP Rooftop Gardening Proposals.

You can also check out past grant projects and guidelines.

Who can Apply?

The following are eligible to apply:

  • a) Singaporeans;

  • b) Singapore permanent residents;

  • c) Merchants association;

  • d) Residents' committee/network;

  • e) Schools;

  • f) Non-profit organisations

*Submissions must be made by Singapore Citizens/ Permanent Residents aged above 17 years.
*Submission of proposals by government agencies and/or Town Councils on behalf of community stakeholders will not be accepted.

When to apply?

The Project Fund and Building Fund are open for applications throughout the year. Application should be submitted at least 8 weeks before the project start date.

For MSCP Rooftop Gardening Proposals, applications are open from:

  • March – April; and
  • September – October

How much funding can you receive?

For Project Fund and Building Fund proposals, successful applicants can receive 100% funding for project expenditure, capped at $20,000. Projects that are activity-based would be subjected to a 25% grant on outsourced manpower costs and 20% grant cap on F&B and prizes.

For MSCP Rooftop Gardening Proposals accepted by HDB, HDB will carry out the conversion of the MSCP roof decks into community/allotment gardens using our Prefabricated Extensive Green (PEG) Roof Tray System. In addition, if applicants wish to improve the completed gardens with other works e.g. setting up of rest areas for gardeners, wall/floor murals, etc , they can be supported with a funding of up to $20,000.

grants_details.guideline_html:
The Love Our ’Hood Fund supports projects that address municipal issues and/or foster a sense of community within the neighbourhood to manage neighbourly issues amicably. Some municipal issues include littering, irresponsible feeding of community animals, noise from neighbours and second-hand smoke.

More details on the grant are available in the grant guidelines.

Who can apply?

For Individuals

  • You must be a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident, who is 18 years old and above.
  • You must be residing in Singapore.

For Organisations

  • The organisation must be:
    • A company that is registered with the Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA); or
    • A not-for-profit organisation that is a Public Company Limited by guarantee registered with
      • Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority (ACRA); or
      • Society registered with Registry of Societies (ROS); or
      • Charitable Trust registered with the Commissioner of Charities (COC); or
      • Co-Operative registered with the Registry of Co-operative Societies; or
      • Trade Union registered with Registry of Trade Unions.

When can I apply?

The application period is open throughout the year. All applications must be submitted at least eight weeks before the project start date to allow sufficient time for clarifications, processing, and administrative arrangements.

How much funding can you receive?

You may receive up to 80% of supported project expenditure on a reimbursement basis, capped at $20,000 per project. Specific funding levels would vary based on the merits of each project.

grants_details.name: OUR SINGAPORE FUND (Community)
grants_details.desc: Have an idea for projects that bring communities together, that promotes Singapore's national identity and shared values? Find out if you are eligible to apply for Our Singapore Fund.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Our Singapore Fund (Community) supports meaningful citizen-led projects that strengthens our solidarity as a society through three main themes:
  1. Belong: Projects whose content and participant engagement help participants build an appreciation of Singapore’s shared values and a sense of belonging to Singapore.
  2. Build: Projects which encourage participants to contribute to community needs and/or the social good.
  3. Bond: Projects which bring different groups/communities together to build mutual understanding and respect.

Who can apply?

For individuals

  • You must be a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident who is 18 years old and above and residing in Singapore.
  • SingPass will be required to log into the Our SG Grants portal to submit an application.

For groups

For organisation and companies

  • The organisation or company must be registered in Singapore.
  • CorpPass will be required to log into the Our SG Grants portal to submit an application.
  • Contact person/ applicant must be a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident who is 18 years old and above and residing in Singapore.

For schools/ youth groups

  • The applicant must be a staff of the school/member of the youth group (a Singapore Citizen/Permanent Resident who is 18 years old and above and residing in Singapore) Corppass.
  • Unregistered youth groups may apply as an individual however, please state the name and status of the youth group clearly in the application
  • Note that OSF(C) does not support projects which are part of the education curriculum.

When can I apply?

Our Singapore Fund is open for applications throughout the year. Applications must be submitted at least 8 weeks before the project start date.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicants can receive up to 50% or 80% of supported project expenditure, capped at $20,000.00.

Specific funding levels would vary based on the project's alignment to OSF(C) objectives.

Although funding for projects is capped at $20,000.00, your awarded grant may be less than $20,000.00, subject to project merit, actual expenditures, and assessed qualifying cost etc.

Does my project meet OSF(C)'s requirements?

To find out if your project meets OSF(C)'s eligibility, funding requirements and objectives please complete the Applicant checklist before submitting your application.

More details are available in the FAQs.

grants_details.name: Pay-It-Forward Award
grants_details.desc: Each conferred Youth Corps leader is awarded $3,000 project grant to initiate and sustain ground-up initiatives to serve the local community.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Pay-It-Forward Award (PIFA), administered by Youth Corps Singapore, is a project grant awarded to each conferred leader to initiate and sustain ground-up initiatives that serve the local community. The grant aims to enable Youth Corps Leaders to continue contributing to the local community after graduating from the Youth Corps Leaders Programme.

PIFA can be used to:

  • Organise youth events/ground-up initiatives; and
  • Mentor/advise/lead and sponsor other youths for community projects.
  • Note: Project must not contain any inflammatory and/or discriminatory elements that may disrupt societal, racial and religious harmony.
Interested applicants are to read the PIFA Funding Guidelines, complete the online application and submit the required documents to NYC at least 8 weeks before the proposed Project Start Date.

Who Can Apply?

  • Leaders who have been successfully conferred upon completing Youth Corps Singapore Leaders Programme
  • Cluster Leaders who have been successfully conferred
  • Within 3 years from the date of conferment, Leaders may apply for PIFA as an individual or a team

When to Apply?

Leaders may start applying for PIFA from the date of conferment at the Youth Corps Leaders Commencement Ceremony.

Application is open throughout the year and must be submitted at least 8 weeks before project commencement date.

How much funding can you receive?

Each successful applicant will receive up to $3,000 in funding (i.e., if the Leader was previously awarded $2,000 for a past project initiative, the Leader will only be able to apply for up to $1,000 for current project).

A team of more than three Youth Corps Leaders with a combined PIFA of $10,000 or more may apply for up to $10,000 for their project initiative.

grants_details.guideline_html:
The Presentation and Participation (Publishing) Grant aims to provide funding to active, professional book publishers or authors who are committed to advancing the arts in Singapore. Applications should be submitted by the publisher of the work. If the work is to be self-published, the writer may apply for the grant.

Applicants must:
  • Have your work commercially available for sale, with effective national and preferably international distribution systems.
  • Issue clear royalty statements on a regular basis and have fulfilled all contractual obligations to writers, illustrators, translators and other copyright licensors.
  • (For translators only) Be a recognised professional translator or have had a least one literary translation published by a recognised publisher.

To ensure this is the right grant for your project, download the grant guidelines from this page. Please note that we’ve revised our grant guidelines on 16 August 2024 and 14 December 2024 and changes will take effect on the respective dates. Please refer to NAC website for more details.

grants_details.name: Productivity and Digitalisation Grant (PDG)
grants_details.desc: PDG supports the sector’s needs by focusing on 5 strategic areas, while promoting productivity and digitalisation.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Productivity and Digitalisation Grant (PDG) is a resource support under the Community Care Digital Transformation Plan (CCDTP).

It aims to support Community Care Organisations to adopt technology as part of their digitalisation journey to improve productivity and optimise manpower; enable better care and stronger care integration; and support sector transformation.

It provides co-funding to defray cost of implementing technology solutions that are aligned to the Technology Directory Roadmap and able to demonstrate its application in the following domains:

  • Productivity and digitalisation focus
  • Impact to organisation
  • Capabilities of organisation to execute project
  • Sustainability of the project

For more details on the CCDTP and Technology Directory Roadmap, click here.

Eligibility

This grant is open to organisations that provide community care services in line with MOH’s licensing or service requirements. The project shall be for its centre that operates in Singapore.

Funding Quantum

Eligible grant applicant may receive funding of up to 85% of the approved costs, capped at a certain amount, depending on the type of technology category.

Application Process

You may submit the online application form throughout the year. Kindly submit one application per project and preferably, one project per centre.

grants_details.name: Professional Capability Grant (Open Grant Call)
grants_details.desc: This category focuses on courses that will develop and retain talents in the social service sector, which includes short to mid-term local and overseas training courses as well as clinical supervision that will build the manpower capability of the SSAs. It also funds social service projects aimed at improving staff competencies and the Sabbatical Leave Scheme (SLS) that focuses on staff wellness.
grants_details.guideline_html:
This category focuses on courses that will develop and retain talents in the social service sector, which includes short to mid-term local and overseas training courses as well as clinical supervision that will build the manpower capability of the SSAs. It also funds social service projects aimed at improving staff competencies and the Sabbatical Leave Scheme (SLS) that focuses on staff wellness.

The five grants under PCG are:

  1. Overseas Training Grant
    The Overseas Training Grant supports short-term overseas training/ conference and study trip, that are not readily available in Singapore. It is open to NCSS-members Social Service Agencies and MSF-funded agencies. The staff must not be receiving other government funding.

  2. Local Training (non-pre-approval)
    The non-pre-approval funding supports short-term social service-related courses and conferences.
    It is open to NCSS-members Social Service Agencies and MSF-funded Agencies. The staff must not be receiving other government funding.

  3. Professional Development Sponsorship
    The Professional Development Sponsorships provides funding for in-service professionals to acquire their first recognised social work and psychology qualifications It also provides training subsidy for other social service-related graduate and post-graduate courses.
    Staff of NCSS member Social Service Agencies (SSAs) and/or MSF-funded agencies. The staff must not be receiving other government funding (except for the subsidy from Ministry of Education) for Graduate Diploma/Degree studies, unless specifically allowed. The staff must also not qualify for other schemes such as Career Conversion Programme (CCP) for social workers and has been accepted into an approved Bachelor/Graduate Diploma/ Masters programme.

  4. Open Grant
    The Open Grant supports clinical supervision, SSA-initiated and centrally driven initiatives, that build the professional capability of the SSA and its staff.
    It is open to NCSS-members Social Service Agencies and MSF-funded Agencies. The staff must not be receiving other government funding.

  5. Sabbatical Leave Scheme (SLS)
    The Sabbatical Leave Scheme (SLS) aims to provide social service professionals (who have at least 5 years of direct work experience in their respective professional fields within the sector) with 10 weeks of paid leave to recharge and refresh themselves.
    It is open to social service professionals who are registered social workers, occupational therapists, physiotherapists, speech therapists, psychologists, counsellors and EPIC teachers with Advanced Diploma in Early Childhood Intervention (Special Needs)

Please refer to the website for more information.

grants_details.name: Programme X Fund
grants_details.desc: Programme X Fundings supports youth-initiated projects, enabling young changemakers to drive positive change in the Singapore community and society.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Programme X is a programme launched in 2019 by Youth Corps Singapore (YCS) in partnership with the Institutes of Higher Learning (IHLs) to promote youth volunteerism and develop the next generation of youth community service leaders.

The ‘X’ stands for Multiplier, and the mission is to raise up youth Multipliers to rally and lead their peers in their charge to create a positive impact on the community. This is in response to changing and unmet social needs, which requires volunteers to step up to play an active role in coming alongside Social Service Agencies (SSAs) to tackle these issues and needs.

Who can apply?

Singapore Citizens and Permanent Residents (PR) who have participated in Programme X, within one year of their participation, and are multipliers.

Applicants must complete the 'Successful Funding Application' module on LMS

When can I apply?

Interested applicants should review the Funding Guidelines and submit their online application with the required documents through the OurSG Grants portal. Applications must be submitted at least 8 weeks before the proposed project start date.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicants will receive an in-principle fund approval of up to $3,000 or 100% of the total allowable project cost, whichever is lower.

grants_details.name: SG60 Towards Sustainability Fund
grants_details.desc: Explore funding for social service agencies (SSAs) to kickstart their capabilities in measuring, monitoring, and reporting the effectiveness of their programmes.
grants_details.guideline_html:
As we celebrate SG60, the SG60 Towards Sustainability Fund aims to recognise the contributions of social service agencies (SSAs) to Singapore. It supports SSAs in taking first steps to building critical capabilities in measuring, monitoring, and reporting the effectiveness of their programmes with the goal of improving the quality of lives of individuals and families they serve. Stronger outcomes reporting will also enable SSAs to scale high-impact programmes and attract more resources from funders.

Who can apply?

NCSS Full Members who can meet the requirements of this fund.

Funding Requirements

  • Be a NCSS Full Member
  • Provide information of the identified programme not funded by any government agency and submit the Theory of Change (TOC). The programme criteria are:
    • Provides direct intervention to service users, i.e. structured services with a clear start and end points to achieve specific client outcomes
    • Programme identified has the highest total expenditure, among all the other programmes and/or serves the largest number of service users
    • The programme serves at least one of ComChest’s 5 causes which are Adults with Disabilities, Children with Special Needs & Youth-At-Risk, Families in Need of Assistance, People with Mental Health Conditions and Seniors in Need of Support
  • Agency must commit to share outcome data with NCSS should agency be further supported in other funding (e.g. Transformation Sustainability Scheme) to strengthen programme evaluation capabilities
  • Agency must send at least one representative to attend a session organised by NCSS on how better impact measurement can help to attract more resources from funders

When can I apply?

From 19 September 2025 to 31 March 2026.

How much funding can you receive?

$30,000.00

grants_details.name: SUSTAIN THE ARTS (stART) FUND (ORGANISATION FUNDING)
grants_details.desc: The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund is an initiative by the National Arts Council (NAC), supported by the private sector to boost the long-term sustainability of small arts organisations, and to nurture a culture of giving to the arts.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund provides funding to arts organisations to help scale-up and attain Charity and/or IPC status. Through the organisation funding, the stART Fund supports a broad range of operational needs and capacity building efforts in ensuring that eligible small arts groups can establish robust governance structures and enhance the long-term viability by improving their organisation structure.

Who can apply?

Arts organisations who are registered with Commissioner of Charities (COC), Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore non-profit Companies Limited by Guarantee (ACRA non-profit CLG) or the Registry of Societies (ROS), and have total operating expenditure (TOE) of below $1M based on last audited financial statements.

When can I apply?

The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund is open for application once a year. The 2026 cycle will be from 5th January 2026 to 27th February 2026.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applications for organisation track will be awarded a flat quantum of $30,000.

grants_details.desc: The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund is an initiative by the National Arts Council (NAC), supported by the private sector to boost the long-term sustainability of small arts organisations, and to nurture a culture of giving to the arts.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund provides funding to arts organisations to help create and present quality programmes that contribute to the vibrancy of Singapore's arts and culture ecosystem. Such programmes include those with community impact that enable more people to enjoy the arts, enhance the arts experience through digital technology, and encourage audiences to reflect on and celebrate Singapore's cultural identity.

Who can apply?

Arts organisations who are registered with Commissioner of Charities (COC), Accounting and Corporate Regulatory Authority of Singapore (ACRA) or the Registry of Societies (ROS), and have total operating expenditure (TOE) of below $1M based on last audited financial statements.

Arts organisations with Institution of Public Character (IPC) status with a TOE below $1M are eligible for the stART Fund programme track. However, they are only allowed to receive funding from the stART Fund for one cycle.

When can I apply?

The Sustain The Arts (stART) Fund is open for application once a year. The 2026 cycle will be from 5th January 2026 to 27th February 2026.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applications to the Programme track may receive a fund quantum between $20,000 to $50,000.

grants_details.name: Tote Board Arts Fund
grants_details.desc: The Tote Board Arts Fund provides support to local artists/arts groups in bringing the arts to communities for people to connect with one another.
grants_details.guideline_html:
An initiative of the Singapore Totalisator Board, the Tote Board Arts Fund provides support to local artists and arts groups in bringing the arts to communities, and creating shared experiences for people to connect with one another. The Fund is managed by a committee appointed by the National Arts Council.

The Tote Board Arts Fund aims to support arts projects of good quality for the enjoyment of Singaporeans. Arts groups and artists are encouraged to engage their local communities, providing them with opportunities to sample, savour, and deepen their appreciation of different art forms.

The grant guidelines are updated regularly. Before proceeding to the application, please download the latest grant guidelines from this page to ensure this is the right grant for your project.

Who can apply?

The Tote Board Arts Fund is open to:
  • Individual Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents recognised by their peers as practising artists;
  • Arts organisation that are either registered as a non-profit entity with ACRA or registered as a society with the Registry of Societies at the time of application; and
  • Informal groups or collectives of which, the majority of members are Singapore Citizens or Permanent Residents (Informal groups or collectives must nominate either a member of the group who is a Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident, or a legally constituted organisation to take legal and financial responsibility on behalf of the group)

When to apply?

Applications must reach Tote Board Arts Fund Secretariat before commencement of your project. Check key dates and application windows for more information.

How much funding can you receive?

The Tote Board Arts Fund supports up to 50% of a realistic budget for all eligible applications, capped at $60,000 per financial year for each applicant.

  • For visual artists, please attach artwork samples of the exhibition.
  • For Theatre and Literary Arts projects, including Festivals, the submission of complete scripts/ manuscripts is required upon application. Translated script(s) in English should be provided for non-English manuscript(s).

grants_details.name: Tote Board Better Health Fund (TBBHF)
grants_details.desc: The Tote Board Better Health Fund (TBBHF) is a seed fund to pilot innovative programmes with a potential to scale within the community care sector.
grants_details.guideline_html:
The Tote Board Better Health Fund (TBBHF) is a seed fund to pilot innovative programmes with a potential to scale within the community care sector. There are three key priorities under TBBHF: Care and Support, Care Integration and Emerging Areas.

  1. Care and Support – To empower individuals and expand the range of approaches that allow them to age healthily and well.
  2. Care Integration – To strengthen care services and enable the community in achieving a seamless continuum of care for clients.
  3. Emerging Areas – To energise the ecosystem to be future-ready in addressing emerging priorities and gaps.

Click here for more information on TBBHF.

Who Can Apply?

To be eligible for TBBHF, the applicant must be one of the following organisations or institution:

  • Co-operatives
  • Non-Profit Organisations (Companies Limited by Guarantee, Charity Trusts and Societies) / Social Service Agencies
  • Social Enterprises which are members of the Singapore Centre for Social Enterprise (raiSE)
  • Government Agencies
  • Regional Healthcare Systems
  • Public Healthcare Institutions
  • Grassroots Organisations
  • Private service providers that serve subsidised clients (e.g. private nursing homes on portable subsidy)

AND the applicant has General Reserves of not more than three years of Total Operating Expenditure.

When to Apply?

Applications are accepted throughout the year and project can only commence two (2) months after approval from Evaluation Panel (EP) has been obtained. The application closing and EP meeting dates are as follows:

Application ClosingEvaluation Panel (EP) meeting conducted in
31 MarchJuly
31 JulyNovember
30 NovemberMarch of following year

How much funding can you receive?

TBBHF funds projects based on a quarterly reimbursement basis, at up to 90% of supported costs.

Funding CriteriaFunding Quantum
Programme serves an unmet need and uses a new method or approach which aims to achieve transformative impact in the landscape.90% of supported costs.
Programme serves an unmet need and is an existing service model rolled out to a new target group.70% of supported costs.

grants_details.name: YOUNG CHANGEMAKERS (YCM)
grants_details.desc: Have a cool idea that can contribute to the community? The Young ChangeMakers Grant supports youth-initiated projects that benefit the Singapore community and society.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Have a cool idea that can contribute to the community? The Young ChangeMakers Grant supports youth-initiated projects that benefit the Singapore community and society. It also helps to empower youth as decision makers to evaluate projects and mentor project applicants.

Who can apply?

Singaporean or Singaporean Permanent Residents (PR) youths residing locally between 15 – 35 years old by birth year.

When can I apply?

Application is open throughout the year and must be submitted at least 8 weeks before 1st Saturday of project implementation month.

How much funding can I receive?

Successful applicants will receive an in-principle grant approval of up to $3,000 or up to 100% of supported cost, whichever is lower. Projects that demonstrate exceeding merits in terms of project scale and impact will be awarded up to $5,000 or up to 100% of supported cost, whichever is lower.

Download the YCM Factsheet to find out more about the YCM Grant:

  • For applications before 1st August 2024, please click here
  • For applications from 1st August 2024, please click here

Embarking on a youth-led Heritage project?

Co-presented by the NYC YCM and National Heritage Board (NHB), the Young ChangeMakers – Youth Heritage Kickstarter Fund (YCM – YHKF) offers additional funding and resources to empower youths to take an active role in preserving and safeguarding Singapore’s heritage. If you wish to promote the appreciation and understanding of Singapore’s heritage, you may be funded up to $5,000 or $7,000 to kickstart your project!

To find out more about the YCM – YHKF, check out the factsheet here. Interested and eligible applicants can apply to the YCM – YHKF via the YCM grant card (this page) and select ‘Culture & Heritage’ as the project category.

Embarking on a youth-led sporting initiative?

The Young ChangeMakers - YouthCreates (Sport) grant, jointly offered by the NYC YCM and SportSG YouthCreates, can help bring your ideas to life! Projects that reach out and engage the community through sporting or physical activities could receive funding of up to $6,000 or $8,000.

Ready to make a difference to the community through sports? Find out more about the YCM - YC (Sport) grant here, and submit your application through the YCM grant card (this page) and select 'Sport' as your project category.

Embarking on a youth-led Bilingualism project?

In partnership with the Lee Kuan Yew Fund for Bilingualism, the Young ChangeMakers – Bilingualism grant offers additional funding for youths to promote bilingualism. If you are keen to promote bilingualism and encourage the usage of both English and Mother Tongue languages in daily lives, you may be funded up to $6,000 or $8,000 to kickstart your project!

Find out more about the YCM – Bilingualism grant here and apply via the YCM grant card (this page).

Got a brilliant idea for public transport?

The Young ChangeMakers - Caring SG Commuters grant in collaboration with the Public Transport Council (PTC) is here to empower young innovators like you to create a more gracious, caring and inclusive commuting experience for everyone!

Score up to $5,000 for your project (or even $7,000 if your idea is next-level) and turn your vision to reality. Whether you are dreaming up creative campaigns, designing inclusive solutions, or building stronger community vibes on our trains and buses, this grant is your launchpad.

Find out more about the YCM - Caring SG Commuters grant here and apply via the YCM grant card (this page) to make a difference today because the best ideas come from everyday commuters like you!

For queries about the YCM grant, you may contact our friendly grant managers at partnership_enquiries@nyc.gov.sg.

The Youth Corps Affiliate Project Grant, administered by Youth Corps Singapore, is a funding initiative that supports Affiliate-led projects serving the Singapore community and society. The grant enables young changemakers to initiate and sustain ground-up initiatives that drive positive change. Successful applicants will receive funding to implement their proposed projects.

Who can apply?

Affiliates (EXCO team) who have been successfully appointed and are currently part of the Youth Corps Affiliate Scheme. Affiliates may apply anytime within their 3-year appointment term.

When can I apply?

Interested applicants should review the Funding Guidelines and submit their online application with the required documents through the OurSG Grants portal. Applications must be submitted at least 8 weeks before the proposed project start date.

How much funding can you receive?

Funding up to 100% of total allowed project costs, up to $3,000 per project, with a maximum of two projects funded per financial year (1 Apr – 31 Mar).

grants_details.name: Youth Corps Expedition Project
grants_details.desc: Supports youths embarking on Service-Learning projects involving communities in Asia, with a focus on the ASEAN member states, China and India.
grants_details.guideline_html:
Youth Corps Expedition Project (YEP) is a Service-Learning programme by Youth Corps Singapore to nurture confident and resilient youths who are active citizens with the desire to make a difference both at home and overseas. YEP involves communities in Asia with a focus on the ASEAN member states, China or India. The grant supports youths endorsed by educational institutions and not-for-profit organisation based and registered in Singapore to embark on community building projects, leadership and project management training within the programme. For more information on funding and eligibility, read the grant guidelines.

Who can apply?

Anyone in the team can submit the application:

  • Team Leader must be Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident (PR);
  • At least 80% of team, including Team Leader, must be Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident (PR);
  • Team Member has to be between 15 – 35 years old.
  • More details on eligibility are available in the grant guidelines.

How much funding can you receive?

YEP teams can receive funding for up to 60% of total allowable projects costs, subject to a cap of S$1,000 per pax per eligible participant.

When to apply?

The preparation phase may take 3 to 5 months to complete. You should start the planning process early and apply no later than 2 months before the start date of your YEP Overseas Project to be considered for funding. Ensure you have the following required documents ready when you submit your application.

How can you check if participants are eligible for funding?

Start a new application for your project and fill in the team name list to see which participants are eligible for YEP funding. You can repeat this step as many times as you need, before submitting the application.

grants_details.guideline_html:
YEP-GO provides a platform for youths to continue volunteering with the overseas communities without travel. Youths can connect with overseas partner organisations to develop programmes such as online classes, trainings or skilled volunteering through virtual means.

A YEP-GO project should:

  • Involve communities in the ASEAN member states, India and China;
  • Be endorsed by an Endorsing Organisation (EO) which is a recognised education institution or not-for-profit organisation based and registered in Singapore;
  • Complete three key phases, i.e. Preparation, Online Project and Project Closure.

Who can apply?

Anyone in the team can submit the application:

  • Team Leader must be Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident (PR);
  • At least 80% of team, including Team Leader, must be Singapore Citizen or Permanent Resident (PR);
  • Team Member has to be between 15 – 35 years old.

More details on eligibility are available in the grant guidelines.

When can I apply?

Application should be submitted at least 2 months before the start of the Online Project.

How much funding can you receive?

Successful applicants will receive 80% of total qualifying project costs, capped at $3,000 per team.
